update.description:
The PR depends on pull request #60. Please review that one first.

Adds 10000ms latency to downlink and uplink, which adds up to a 20 second round trip latency
update.title: Add latency to traffic shapper

content.raw: Since these chances are already included in the other PR I tested, yes, it LGTM
content.html: Since these chances are already included in the other PR I tested, yes, it LGTM

content.raw: @preyna does this PR look good to you?
content.html: @preyna does this PR look good to you?

content.raw: ya the `fc_monitor` branch includes changes here in this PR
content.html: ya the fc_monitor branch includes changes here in this PR

content.raw: I think I may know why. The old AMIs are using old srcsim version which has a different message definition. Executing `src_t.rb` directly should work but not when starting simulation tasks.
content.html: I think I may know why. The old AMIs are using old srcsim version which has a different message definition. Executing src_t.rb directly should work but not when starting simulation tasks.

content.raw:
I just tested this other PR: #!/osrf/cloudsim-sim/pull-requests/75/monitor-ros-master-from-fc-and-restart-tc/diff  . If that already included the latency in the branch I merged , then you can consider this one as tested too  :) 
Can you confirm if fc_monitor branch had the latency stuff too ?
content.html: I just tested this other PR: #!/osrf/cloudsim-sim/pull-requests/75/monitor-ros-master-from-fc-and-restart-tc/diff . If that already included the latency in the branch I merged , then you can consider this one as tested too :) Can you confirm if fc_monitor branch had the latency stuff too ?

content.raw: ok I see thanks for testing. Let me merge this branch with our latest changes and try it out
content.html: ok I see thanks for testing. Let me merge this branch with our latest changes and try it out

content.raw:
Unfortunately , testing with these AMIs (the old ones from the test instructions) I couldn't make it work. I don't notice the latency.
I got some ```RTNETLINK answers: No such file or directory``` , and some error related to ```ifb0```. 

{noformat}
name: src-0.1.17
ami-c4a180a4

FC: 
name: src-fc-0.1.12a
ami-8f2909ef 
{noformat}

I also tried with latest AMI for the simulator and test AMI  src-fc-0.1.12a for the FC, but wasn't able to get the latency activated either.  
Can this be tested with latest AMIs and this branch up-to-date with default branch ? (I see it is around 30 commits away)
content.html:
Unfortunately , testing with these AMIs (the old ones from the test instructions) I couldn't make it work. I don't notice the latency. I got some RTNETLINK answers: No such file or directory , and some error related to ifb0.

{noformat} name: src-0.1.17 ami-c4a180a4

FC: name: src-fc-0.1.12a ami-8f2909ef {noformat}

I also tried with latest AMI for the simulator and test AMI src-fc-0.1.12a for the FC, but wasn't able to get the latency activated either.
Can this be tested with latest AMIs and this branch up-to-date with default branch ? (I see it is around 30 commits away)

content.raw: Ok , great. Let me try again
currently we're setting it to 250ms one way so iperf should work now
content.html: currently we're setting it to 250ms one way so iperf should work now

content.raw: [This page](https://netbeez.net/2016/02/24/how-to-adjust-the-tcp-window-size-limit-on-linux/) looks interesting. It talks about using iperf and updating system TCP window size
content.html: This page looks interesting. It talks about using iperf and updating system TCP window size

content.raw: ya I haven't figured out how to get `iperf` to work with this large latency over TCP. I think we may be running into a high [bandwidth-delay product](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bandwidth-delay_product) problem. I tried changing the TCP window size but it wouldn't let me go over 416KB
content.html: ya I haven't figured out how to get iperf to work with this large latency over TCP. I think we may be running into a high bandwidth-delay product problem. I tried changing the TCP window size but it wouldn't let me go over 416KB

content.raw: is is OK for the iperf to give connection timeout (OCU client , FC server) after adding the latency ?
content.html: is is OK for the iperf to give connection timeout (OCU client , FC server) after adding the latency ?

content.raw:
Thanks Ian. I can confirm a latency is noticed when doing the iperf test . The latency is noticed before the connection is established. 

The results of the iperf are the following: 

FC acting as the client (`iperf -c 192.168.2.150`): 
```
$ iperf -c 192.168.2.150
------------------------------------------------------------
Client connecting to 192.168.2.150, TCP port 5001
TCP window size: 45.0 KByte (default)
------------------------------------------------------------
[  3] local 192.168.2.10 port 52788 connected with 192.168.2.150 port 5001
[ ID] Interval       Transfer     Bandwidth
[  3]  0.0-61.0 sec   256 KBytes  34.4 Kbits/sec
```

OCU as the client:
```
$ iperf -c 192.168.2.10
connect failed: Connection timed out
```
content.html:
Thanks Ian. I can confirm a latency is noticed when doing the iperf test . The latency is noticed before the connection is established.

The results of the iperf are the following:

FC acting as the client (iperf -c 192.168.2.150): 

$ iperf -c 192.168.2.150
------------------------------------------------------------
Client connecting to 192.168.2.150, TCP port 5001
TCP window size: 45.0 KByte (default)
------------------------------------------------------------
[  3] local 192.168.2.10 port 52788 connected with 192.168.2.150 port 5001
[ ID] Interval       Transfer     Bandwidth
[  3]  0.0-61.0 sec   256 KBytes  34.4 Kbits/sec

OCU as the client:

$ iperf -c 192.168.2.10
connect failed: Connection timed out
